block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended May 19, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editor's Choice Other ecent books of particular interest

THE OCCUPATION OF IRAQ: Winning the War, Losing the Peace, by Ali A. Allawi. (Yale University, $28.) Iraq's former defense minister tries to pinpoint the role of the country's new political class in shaping the catastrophe there.
THE LIZARD CAGE, by Karen Connelly. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $26.) Connelly's novel bares a Burmese political prisoner's innermost self.
THE SEA LADY: A Late Romance, by Margaret Drabble. (Harcourt, $24.) After 30 years of shunning each other, an estranged couple meet again.
VARIETIES OF DISTURBANCE: Stories, by Lydia Davis. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, paper, $13.) Dispensing with straight narrative, Davis microscopically examines language and thought.
THE CANON: A Whirligig Tour of the Beautiful Basics of Science, by Natalie Angier. (Houghton Mifflin, $27.) A journalist surveys the fundamentals she believes educated people should master.
CITY OF ORANGES: An Intimate History of Arabs and Jews in Jaffa, by Adam LeBor. (Norton, paper, $14.95.) Jaffa from the perspective of a half-dozen clans intertwined in peace and conflict.
FLIGHT, by Sherman Alexie. (Black Cat/Grove/Atlantic, paper, $13.) A troubled teenager time-travels to hot spots in American Indian history.
THE DEVIL IN THE KITCHEN: Sex, Pain, Madness, and the Making of a Great Chef, by Marco Pierre White with James Steen. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A British bad boy's moving memoir.
THE LAST TYCOONS: The Secret History of Lazard FrÃ

Weeks
This Last On
Week Week List FICTION

1 2 1 THE 6TH TARGET, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) In San Francisco, children and their nannies are disappearing, and Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women's Murder Club investigate.
1 BAD LUCK AND TROUBLE, by Lee Child. (Delacorte, $26.) Jack Reacher must discover who is hunting down members of a team of former military investigators.
1 INVISIBLE PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $26.95.) The Minneapolis detective Lucas Davenport finds connections between the murder of several elderly residents and a political scandal.
4 3 3 THE YIDDISH POLICEMEN'S UNION, by Michael Chabon. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) A detective investigates a neighbor's murder in a Jewish settlement in Alaska.
5 2 4 SIMPLE GENIUS, by David Baldacci. (Warner, $26.99.) Two former Secret Service agents investigate a scientist's murder while one battles her own demons.
6 4 5 THE CHILDREN OF HÃRIN, by J. R. R. Tolkien. Edited by Christopher Tolkien. Illustrated by Alan Lee. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) In Middle-earth, an evil lord wants to destroy his rival's children.
1 Pearl Harbor, by Newt Gingrich and William R. Forstchen. (Thomas Dunne, $25.95.) The buildup to the historic attack, with an alternative ending.
8 7 3 RANT, by Chuck Palahniuk. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The ''oral biography'' of a serial killer.
9 6 5 THE WOODS, by Harlan Coben. (Dutton, $26.95.) A prosecutor must confront family secrets when new evidence surfaces about a murder and disappearance at a summer camp 20 years earlier.
10 8 11 NINETEEN MINUTES, by Jodi Picoult. (Atria, $26.95.) The aftermath of a high school shooting reveals the fault lines in a small New Hampshire town.
11 5 7 I HEARD THAT SONG BEFORE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) A woman marries a childhood acquaintance suspected of several murders.
12 12 4 BODY SURFING, by Anita Shreve. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) A woman takes a job as a tutor and becomes involved in a wealthy family's tensions and rivalries.
13* 9 5 THE GOOD HUSBAND OF ZEBRA DRIVE, by Alexander McCall Smith. (Pantheon, $21.95.) The eighth novel in the No. 1 Ladies' Detective Agency series.
1 THE QUEST, by Wilbur Smith. (Thomas Dunne, $27.95.) In ancient Egypt, a magus searches for the cause of a series of plagues.
1 FALLING MAN, by Don DeLillo. (Scribner, $26.) The effect of 9/11 on a middle-class Manhattan family.
16* 13 3 ALL TOGETHER DEAD, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $24.95.) Sookie Stackhouse, a New Orleans cocktail waitress, is swept up in the intrigue of a vampire summit.
Weeks
This Last On
Week Week List NONFICTION
1 4 3 GOD IS NOT GREAT, by Christopher Hitchens. (Twelve, $24.99.) Religion as a malignant force in the world.
2 1 6 EINSTEIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $32.) A biography based on newly released personal letters.

3 5 3 ANIMAL, VEGETABLE, MIRACLE, by Barbara Kingsolver with Steven L. Hopp and Camille Kingsolver. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) The novelist and her family spend a year eating homegrown or local food; an argument for diversified farms and sustainable agriculture.
1 PLATO and A PLATYPUS WALK INTO A BAR, by Thomas Cathcart and Daniel Klein. (Abrams Image, $18.95.) A humorous tour of philosophical traditions.
5 6 14 A LONG WAY GONE, by Ishmael Beah. (Sarah Crichton/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A former child soldier from Sierra Leone describes his drug-crazed killing spree and his return to humanity.
1 JESUS OF NAZARETH, by Benedict XVI. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The pope discusses Jesus' identity as revealed in the Gospels.
7* 9 2 PRESIDENTIAL COURAGE, by Michael Beschloss. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) Profiles of nine presidents who had the courage to make unpopular decisions.
8 2 3 AT THE CENTER OF THE STORM, by George Tenet. (HarperCollins, $30.) The former director of the Central Intelligence Agency looks back on his career.

9 7 5 WHERE HAVE ALL THE LEADERS GONE?, by Lee Iacocca. (Scribner, $25.) The former C.E.O. of Chrysler protests the lack of political and business leadership on issues like health care and energy policy.

10 12 2 TALES FROM Q SCHOOL, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $26.99.) Inside the 2005 PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament, which determines whether a golfer will have a slot on the PGA Tour, from the author of ''A Good Walk Spoiled.''

11 3 7 PAULA DEEN: IT AIN'T ALL ABOUT THE COOKIN', by Paula Deen with Sherry Suib Cohen. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A memoir with recipes from the Southern cooking impresario (Food Network shows, restaurants, cookbooks, magazine).
12 14 10 HOW DOCTORS THINK, by Jerome Groopman. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) A doctor and New Yorker staff writer describes how doctors arrive at diagnoses.
13 11 4 THE BLACK SWAN, by Nassim Nicholas Taleb. (Random House, $26.95.) The role of the unexpected.
14 8 42 I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at aging from a novelist and screenwriter (''When Harry Met Sally'').
1 RICKLES' BOOK, by Don Rickles with David Ritz. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A memoir by the insult comedian.
